metadata.title: CASE 282/04: Investigation Task Force: Irregularities in Pristina Airport Procurement
metadata.primary_source: United Nations Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo

overview: This report investigates suspected irregularities and corruption in the procurement process for extending the cargo apron at Pristina International Airport, as detailed in an audit published on 28th February 2003.

applicable_laws.excerpt: The law applicable in Kosovo shall be the regulations promulgated by the SRSG and subsidiary instruments, and the law in force on 22 March 1989.
Staff members shall uphold the highest standards of efficiency, competence and integrity.
Competition among and participation in the procurement process shall be maximised.

methodology.description: The investigation was conducted pursuant to Executive Decision No 2003/16. Enquiries were made through interviews with individuals and review of documents obtained from Pristina Airport Administration and Pillar IV.
documents_reviewed: Cargo Apron Extension evaluation report dated 2001-08-02

background.context: The investigation was initiated following an audit report, prompting concerns over procurement practices at Pristina International Airport.
entities_involved: UNMIK Office of the Legal Adviser
Military Units of the Kosovo Force (KFOR)
timeline: 2001-09-11: Contract for Cargo Apron Extension signed
2001-05-18: Interoffice memorandum related to tender offers dated

allegations.description: Bid opening committee members also part of the technical evaluation committee.
Contract not reviewed by the UNMIK Legal Adviser.
Vendor self-certified compliance with contract requirements.
Interoffice memorandum suggesting pre-selection of vendors may be incorrectly dated.
allegations.findings: Date on the memorandum may be incorrectly dated.

allegations.description: Tender documents prepared using excerpts from a third-party study.
allegations.findings: Did not comply with Article 23.3 of the UNMIK Finance Administrative Instruction 1999/2.

allegations.description: Vendor self-certified its own work, presenting a conflict of interest.
allegations.findings: Evidence indicated this act potentially compromised the tender process.

findings: Procurement processes at Pristina Airport were compromised.
Regulatory breaches identified in multiple procurement stages.
Tender documents for the cargo apron did not comply with the requirements of Article 23.4 of the UNMIK Finance Administrative Instruction 1999/2.

violations.excerpt: Infractions noted in unclear tender specifications and committee involvement.

actions: Review and tighten procurement processes at Pristina Airport.
Ensure independent verification for contract compliance.
Revise tender specifications to enhance clarity and compliance.
UNMIK to refer all contracts for legal advice before signatures to reduce liability issues.
Ensure staff understand compliance with UNMIK Public Procurement Regulation No 2004/3.
UNMIK to ensure independent evaluations for final contracted products.
DPKO to take action regarding DOTI Official 2 currently with MONUC.
